urn:contentItem:5V50-YCP1-F0J6-J1TG-00000-00Ballarat crews attack fires2019-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Ballarat crews attack firesAlex Ford

In an Australian first, Ballarat's helicopter firefighting crews have completed night aerial water bombing at the huge Rosedale bushfire this week.

The successful operations follow training conducted locally in November.

Helicopters from Ballarat and Mangalore were deployed on Friday, and are still active.

The 12,000 hectare fire is burning six kilometres south of Rosedale, and was contained on Tuesday afternoon.

260 firefighters, 48 trucks, and 11 aircraft were on the 70 kilometre fire front Monday night, improving control lines.

Night fire suppression operations trial operational lead Wayne Rigg said the aerial crews had made a huge difference after two years of preparation - he was working until 3am on Monday night ensuring the crews operated safely.

"There's been a lot of hard work from a lot of people in a great team to develop systems and processes that have held up very well in the first deployment this week at the Rosedale fire," he said.

"We've got the ability to extend our daytime firefighting with aerial assets into the night, and even now, from what we've been seeing, it's providing an enormous benefit.

"The pilots with night vision goggles, that technology is a game changer, because in the day time, with the smoke, and looking at what's going on, it's sometimes difficult to find exactly where the target is.

"The goggles intensify light, and the fire is a light source."

Mr Rigg also thanked the hundreds of ground firefighters.

"We need to put this in perspective ... our volunteers, CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria, the State Emergency Service, they're the ones doing the hard work, we're there to help and support them," he said.

"This just gives an additional level of support that was never available before.'

Difficult wind conditions have caused flareups since Friday, with the wind changing direction to an easterly yesterday.

The fire has burnt 2000 hectares of pine plantation, but no lives or property has been lost, though smokey conditions have affected people across the region.

The arson squad is investigating the cause of the fire.

While the fire is in the same region as the Esso Longford gas plants and the Loy Yang coal plant, neither are under threat, nor is the Fulham Correctional Centre.

The Princes Highway remains open, but some roads are closed, and firefighters are expected to be on the scene for weeks to extinguish the fire.

Fire restrictions are still in force in Ballarat - for more information, check the CFA's website.

urn:contentItem:5V4T-2NX1-JD34-V0JX-00000-00Temperatures on the rise2019-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Temperatures on the riseLachlan Williams

Wimmera towns followed the statewide upwards trend of rising temperatures throughout 2018.

Horsham, Stawell, Ararat, Nhill, Edenhope and Warracknabeal all experienced warmer maximum temperatures than the long term average for their respective regions. Ararat experienced the largest differential to the long term average, with 2018 1.7 degrees warmer.

While Stawell's 2018 maximum average was up by 0.7 of a degree from its long term average, the average high of 21.3 degrees for the calendar year was the equal second highest on record.

The top average temperature for a year for Stawell is 21.5 degrees in 2014.

Warracknabeal was up by 1.2 degrees while the other centres experienced warmer temperatures between 0.4 and 0.7 of a degree.

Warracknabeal also broke a record last year, with the maximum of 37.2 degrees on April 11 the hottest day during the fourth month of the year for the town since records have been kept.

Victoria had another year in the top 10 of all time, while nationally the figure is even more stark.

The country experienced its third hottest year in history and that's a long-term trend unlikely to break any time soon as every year since 1978 has been above the 1961-90 average for mean temperatures.

All but one of the country's top 10 hottest years have occurred since 2005, a result "in line with long-term trends resulting from anthropogenic climate change", the Bureau of Meteorology said in its summary on 2018's national weather.

"Up until the middle of December, more than two-thirds of Australia was recording very much above average daytime temperatures for 2018," it said.

"Pockets of the nation, such as East Gippsland and inland northern NSW, were enduring their hottest year on record for maximums."

Across the world, temperatures are now about 1.1 degrees above the pre-industrial times.

Australia's climate has warmed by just more than one degree since 1910, leading to an increase in the frequency of extreme heat events. Bureau of Meteorology climate monitoring manager Dr Karl Braganza said the warming trend in Australia was contributing to an increase in extreme fire weather.

"Fire weather in Australia is largely monitored using the Forest Fire Danger Index, which estimates fire danger on any given day," he said.

"Monitoring of the FFDI shows there has been an increase in the frequency and severity of fire weather in recent decades.

"This trend in fire weather is particularly noticeable through southern and eastern parts of Australia."

urn:contentItem:5SPX-P2M1-JD34-V26G-00000-00Memorial completed2018-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Memorial completedAmy Maynard

The memorial section of the South Australian Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum (SAVFFM) has officially been completed.

On Tuesday morning invited guests came for a tour of what has been finished so far, and to hear what the next stage is for the SAVFFM.

From Federal Parliament, guests included Member for Barker Tony Pasin, and Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister, Keith Pitt. Mr Pitt is from Queensland, and during his presentation chairman Rex Hall joked that the weather was a little bit nicer where he was from.

Mr Pasin has frequently observed the construction of the SAVFFM, and even spoke about the work of its volunteers in Parliament last week.

"This dedicated group based in Naracoorte, my electorate, who are seeking to establish a museum complex, have done a stellar job over many years," he said.

"From humble beginnings, because of lots of hard work, fundraising and donations from CFS brigades in the region, we now have a memorial to commemorate those who lost their lives."

Member for MacKillop Nick McBride was in Parliament, so staffer Jenny Schilling was his representative.

Local council representatives were Mayor Erika Vickery, CEO Trevor Smart, and Director of Operations Steve Bourne.

From the CFS, there was Region Five Commander John Probert, Colin Chomel of the Mount Lofty CFS, and Vince Monterosa, of the Stirling CFS.

From industry there was David Wheaton (Regional Development), David Bull (Bull Bros) and Chris Gibson (Forestry SA).

Mr Hall said he was appreciative of the amount of construction work Bull Bros had done for the SAVFFM, noting that around 50 per cent of the work had been completed by the Naracoorte-based company.

Forestry SA has been given a flag and a plaque at the memorial site, in memory of the Woods and Forests Department firefighters who lost their lives during the Wandilo forest fire in 1958.

Mr Hall also thanked the volunteers for all of their hard work, and acknowledged the work of those who were absent. In particular, the business plan would not have been completed without Frank Brennan and Robin Holmes.

urn:contentItem:44GH-P2H0-015G-S0MK-00000-00<published>2001-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:33:57Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SPORT; Pg. 28</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire set to blaze at Widden</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Ray Hickson</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WIDDEN Stud sire Charnwood Forest is on fire in the northern hemisphere.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He had 18 individual two-year-old winners in 2000 but Down Under he has had precious few of his progeny grace the tracks.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Charnwood Forest was a top- class miler in his brief career in England.</p><p>He won four races including the Group Two Queen Anne Stakes (8f) at Royal Ascot and Group Two Challenge Stakes at Newmarket, from 11 starts.</p><p> He was also Group One placed three times over eight furlongs in the Sussex Stakes at Goodwood, the St James Palace Stakes at Royal Ascot and the Lockinge Stakes at Newbury. Flemington trainer Leon Corstens is giving two-year-old colt Charnwood Quest his first test under racing conditions today at Moonee Valley.</p><p> His son and racing manager Troy Corstens said the stable was confident the $60,000 Easter Yearling Sales purchase would be seen at his best later in 2001.</p><p> "He's a very nice horse but whatever he does on Saturday he'll improve on," Corstens said.</p><p> "I think he's going to make a really nice three-year-old."</p><p>Charnwood Quest is the last foal of Sir Tristram mare Serves The Purpose who died in 1999.</p><p> Serves The Purpose was the first foal of 1983 Group Three Silver Shadow and Reisling Slipper Trial Stakes winner Purpose.</p><p> She had five foals before her death including city winner Mudejar (by Mukkadamah), who was trained by Corstens early in his career before switching to Bart Cummings.</p><p> The mare has a filly by Johann Quatz in South Africa and has also produced country performers Thundery Knight and Royce.</p><p>Charnwood Quest had an unofficial trial at Flemington on Tuesday, pleasing the stable with his action.</p><p> "He trialled nicely without being sensational but sometimes they surprise you and come out and run really well first up," Corstens said.</p><p> "At this stage we'll go to the paddock unless he wins easily then we'll give him another run.</p><p> "I think he'll get a mile and a quarter (2000m) by the way he looks."</p><p> Charnwood Forest will be well represented by seven yearlings at this month's Magic Millions Sales on the Gold Coast.</p><p> Among his sons and daughters on offer is a filly out of Rhys' Star making her a half sister to AJC Champagne Stakes winner Quick Star.</p><p>  *  *  *</p><p> TOP New Zealand mare Integrate has been retired to stud in Japan after a career which yielded 12 wins and over $400,000 in prize money.</p><p> She won at Group Three level in the Labor Day Stakes at Doomben and is the winner of two Group Two races in New Zealand.</p><p> Integrate couldn't quite crack it for a win in Group One company but was placed five times at that level.</p><p> She will be sent to Shadai Farm in Japan for a mating with their top stayer Sunday Silence.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5RWB-V6B1-DYG0-90G2-00000-00VIC:Fire danger as hot, windy weather hits Vic2018-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Fire danger as hot, windy weather hits VicMELBOURNE March 16

  Victoria - put on your hat, and then hang on to it.
   Hot and windy weather is on its way, and with it is coming a heightened fire risk.


   A total fire ban has been declared for parts of the state on Saturday, with temperatures expected to climb into the high-30s along the Murray and through parts of the Mallee.
   Gusty northerly winds are expected to develop in western and central areas during the afternoon, strengthening overnight and continuing into Sunday morning, as a front moves through.
   "We will see potentially damaging winds developing about much of the southwest central district and also the western south Gippsland district, before those winds ease later in the day on Sunday," Bureau of Meteorology Victoria senior meteorologist Tom Delamotte said on Friday.
   Closer to Melbourne, gusty winds will increase on Saturday afternoon and pick up again early on Sunday as a westerly change comes through, bringing with it gusts of up to 100kmh.
   Most of the state will likely reach temperatures in the low to mid 30s.
   The Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country, Central, North Central and South West regions are subject to the total fire ban, and fire danger ratings are expected to be severe in western and central parts.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said crews were on standby ahead of the warm and windy conditions.
   ?These weather conditions mean any fires that start will be much harder to control," he said in a statement.
   ?We strongly urge the community to consider the value of visiting local forests or parks during periods of high and extreme heat as they can be extremely dangerous under these conditions."
   There is also thunderstorm risk for much of the weekend, starting late on Friday night in the west, though any potential storms are not forecast to bring much rain.

urn:contentItem:5RW7-RTM1-F0J6-J0J7-00000-00fire warning2018-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2fire warningNatalie Croxon

A total fire ban will apply across the whole of central and western Victoria tomorrow, with hot temperatures and wind forecast in an increasingly dry region.

The Bureau of Meteorology expects daytime temperatures in Bendigo will climb from 27 degrees today to 34 degrees tomorrow as northerly winds move through, with similar maximums expected in other parts of the region.

Yesterday the fire danger ratings were set at severe for the Northern Country and Central forecast districts - which include Bendigo, Echuca and Kyneton - and very high for the North Central district.

Firefighters will be on standby and incident management teams will be based in Bendigo and Gisborne in case of fire.

On Sunday, fire danger ratings look set to remain at severe and very high for the Northern Country and North Central districts respectively, while in the Central district it will fall to high.

Temperatures will drop back to the mid to high 20s across most of the region as a cool change arrives on Sunday morning.

BOM senior meteorologist Richard Carlyon said Victoria could expect gusty westerly winds to develop.

Central Victoria has seen no rain since the start of the month, a situation repeated across most of the state.

Mr Carlyon said there was the possibility of showers behind Sunday's change, but northern parts of the state would receive "little if any from this system".

Bendigo last saw rain on February 23, when 2.2 millimetres fell.

Last month's rainfall was below average for most of the region, and the majority of Victoria has received less than 10 per cent of its average annual rainfall, contributing to extreme vegetation dryness across the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria district manager Paul Bates advises anyone going camping this weekend to stay informed and remain observant.

"People must be careful, especially when it comes to campfires as gusty winds will easily carry embers out of a campfire and into the bush," Mr Bates said.

urn:contentItem:5N86-XXN1-JBJ7-N34F-00000-00Why you're seeing smoke around the city2017-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisWhy you're seeing smoke around the cityBhakthi Puvanenthiran

Good conditions have allowed the state government to run planned burns.

Smell smoke? You're not the only one.

Controlled burns are being conducted across Victoria this week as part of the state government's bushfire fuel management plan.

Stable, mild and warm weather this week made for the perfect conditions for more than 100 planned burns from Noojee to Wye River.

The burns have created a haze around Melbourne in recent days but it is not expected to last past Sunday as the operation is winding down.

People wanting to know whether the smoke they see or smell is part of a planned burn can visit a live map on the government's website.

Meanwhile, those worried about smoke in the air are encouraged to check the EPA's Hourly air quality data table.

At 9am on Friday the table stated very poor air quality in Traralgon and Mooroolbark but wind changes mean those conditions could move on quickly.

Any remaining haze is predicted to be swept away by showers forecast for Sunday.

"Planned burning may mean some parks and forests are closed, said Forest Fire Management Victoria Chief Fire Officer Stephanie Rotarangi.

"It may also affect visibility on roads and may result in traffic management measures including speed restrictions and road closures."

"We are taking action now to protect Victoria next summer."

urn:contentItem:54C5-6841-F12F-F52X-00000-00QUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE CREWS RESPOND TO INCIDENTS IN WONBAH, GLASS HOUSE MOUNTAINS AND MT CROSBY2011-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisQUEENSLAND FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE CREWS RESPOND TO INCIDENTS IN WONBAH, GLASS HOUSE MOUNTAINS AND MT CROSBY

BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 29 -- Queensland Fire and Rescue Service issued the following news release:

HOUSE FIRE - MT CROSBY

Five Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) crews responded to reports of a house fire at George Holt Drive, Mount Crosby around 12.40pm. The low-set brick house was well involved when firefighters arrived on scene and the roof had collapsed. The fire was brought under control by 1.15pm. No persons were reported missing and there were no reports of injuries. Fire investigators have been requested to look into the cause of the blaze.

FOREST FIRE - WONBAH (WEST OF GIN GIN)

Multiple QFRS crews are fighting a forest fire on Wonbah Gaeta Road at Wonbah. The fire has been burning for almost a week in inaccessible land and has burnt approximately 1,000 hectares. Firefighters are conducting back burning and constructing fire breaks to protect properties in the area. An aerial fire spotter is also monitoring the fire. There is no direct threat to structures at this time.

SNAKE BITE - GLASS HOUSE MOUNTAINS

Paramedics transported a 40-year-old woman from Meyricks Road on the Glass House Mountains to Nambour Hospital around 12pm with a suspected snake bite. The woman was in a stable condition. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:5PVF-M5C1-F0J6-J09R-00000-00Four years after major fire, experts return for mock emergency2017-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisFour years after major fire, experts return for mock emergencyShana Morgan

Emergency service controllers were on high alert at the Ovens district Incident Control Centre on Tuesday, but it was all for a training exercise just in case the worst happens this fire season.

The last time a major fire was run out of that office was in 2013, when the 55-day Harrietville fire burned through 37,000 hectares of state forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria incident controller Leith McKenzie said four years on, staff were keen for a refresher course in case they were called into action again.

"That was the idea of having a major exercise, to keep people's skills up to date," he said.

"It's working really well."

The scenario involved a hypothetical incident where a fire was started from five separate lightning strikes.

FFM Vic, CFA, Parks Victoria, Victoria Police, Hancock Victorian Plantations and Alpine Council all came together to manage the mock emergency.

"The bush has a different fuel than the open country, so we need to make sure it all works together," Mr McKenzie said.

"The people on the ground know what they're doing. It's mainly communication, it's managing all the people we've got involved."

Firefighters on the ground fighting the blaze need to be supported by these incident controllers, working out the logistics of the fire attack, what resources are needed plus accommodation for staff and briefing media and government ministers.

Mr McKenzie could not predict when the fire danger would begin, but said Ovens district would be ready.

He said water-bombing and reconnaissance aircraft would again be available in for the fire season.

urn:contentItem:5TBV-7DP1-F0J6-J0CB-00000-00Campers urged to stay cautious with campfires during school holidays2018-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisCampers urged to stay cautious with campfires during school holidays

Campers are being urged to remain vigilant and follow campfire safety rules throughout the school holidays.

The term three holidays commenced on Monday, with term four of the school year to get underway on October 8.

Camping, particularly in the Grampians region, is a popular choice for many in the region and from abroad for the holidays, with campfires synonymous with the activity.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting assistant chief fire officer Grant Allan said campfire negligence was a concern in the region and officers would be patrolling to make sure people are doing the right thing.

"School holidays are always a busy time as we see an increase in visitors to the region, we want people to get out there and enjoy our parks and state forests but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," he said.

"Unattended campfires can lead to bushfires, placing the community and firefighters at risk, as well as potentially damaging the environment and affecting industry and recreational users of our public land.

Read more: Police issue warning to Stawell firebugs

"It takes a lot of time, effort and personnel to respond to a fire, so when campfires escape and could have been prevented by following the rules, it's very frustrating."

Regulations of campfires include using a purpose built fireplace or lighting the fire in a trench at least 30 centimetres deep, using logs and branches less than 1m long and ensuring the fire is completely extinguished using water not soil.

On the spot fines of up to $484 can be issued for people breaching campfire safety rules and a person can face a maximum penalty of up to $16,119 if the matter is prosecuted in court.

"Authorised officers will be patrolling our parks and forests over the holiday period to ensure campers are doing the right thing and to educate visitors on campfire safety," Mr Allan said.

"We're asking people to be vigilant and if they see a campfire that doesn't look right or is unattended, then to call 000 It's everyone's responsibility to ensure they follow the campfire safety rules."

More information is available at www.ffm.vic.gov.au/permits-andregulations/fire-restrictions-andregulations

urn:contentItem:5XVP-NJF1-F0JP-W0HN-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 17LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

HOT TOPIC FOREST, FIRE AND CLIMATE CHANGE Miracle of Biblical proportions

THE Boxing Day family gathering at Royal George, near Avoca, has been a tradition for nearly 50 years. We meet on my brother-in-law's farm near what has been the picturesque St Paul's River. From memory this river has never dried until this year where surrounding gums have succumbed to lack of water and are showing signs of advanced dieback. Dead twigs and bare branches form the canopy of these magnificent specimens and are the only remnants of what used to be a thick and healthy foliage crown.

In the face of severe drought and catastrophic fires, I find it incomprehensible that our Government ignores the anthropogenic nature of climate change. Before God has any hope of answering Barnaby Joyce's prayer to alleviate the effects of climate change, God has to convince our Government to act on climate change - a miracle of Biblical proportions.

Ed Sianski West Moonah Stark contrast BOB Brown and Claire Chandler's opposing views in Talking Point (Mercury, December 28) made for interesting reading and show not much has changed over the past 100 years. I was the beneficiary of Kevin Kiernan's book, Eroding The Edges Of Nature, last year and would encourage anyone with an interest in how nature conservation should not be practised, to look it up. Dr Brown made a thorough, though brief, analysis of its contents.

We have just completed our jigsaw of Tasmania after many years. I must say that the best was left until last. Six days from Hobart to the West Coast, the ferry at Corinna across The Pieman River, and into the heart of the Tarkine - surely the most spectacular example of temperate rainforest in the world, though I am sure many will argue its wilderness status.

Parks and Wildlife have done a marvellous job providing low-key access to splendid walks and lookouts. The Julius River picnic area being a prime example. The only downside was at the Trowutta Arch on the fringes of the Tarkine, clearfelling has been allowed right up to the edges of this spectacular geological feature, leaving not much more than a postage stamp amount of rainforest surrounding it. I have come across similar cases of short-sightedness by forestry in the past, clearfelling surrounding the magnificent Leven Canyon Lookout, and clearing around and up to the tall trees of the Styx. Rumour has it forestry is moving in on the Tarkine forests, surely we owe it to future generations to protect this unique environment.

We then come to Claire Chandler and her opposing view, reopening Tasmanian native forests to clearfelling, a process which would reignite the bitter conflict of previous years. Her view that we re-grow native forest after clearing, fails to mention that they are replaced with monoculture, and the complete ecosystem of the native forest is lost forever. She goes on to say that The Wilderness Society and Bob Brown Foundation are permanently at war with tourism proponents trying to expand the state's eco-tourism experience. Those tourism proponents are her Liberal Party colleagues, whose idea of eco-tourism is to privatise Tasmania's wilderness and hand it over to the highest bidder, overriding, or ignoring, any public opinion against their policies.

Mike Dimond Blackmans Bay Optimism BARNABY Joyce apparently thinks that "respecting God is the answer to climate change". A fine sentiment, but ... has God intervened in tsunamis? No. Floods? Nope. Droughts? Nope. Bushfires? Nope. Has Barnaby got optimism? Yep.

Richard WatkinsKingston

urn:contentItem:6005-B4H1-F0J6-J4GN-00000-00Firefighters work hard to contain fires on 'extreme' danger day2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Firefighters work hard to contain fires on 'extreme' danger dayJackson Graham, Katrina Lovell

FIREFIGHTERS sweltered through Monday's "extreme" fire danger as they battled to contain a series of blazes burning in bush near Heywood.

Six fires in the south-west have been burning for 11 days, with one at Lake Condah finally listed as "contained" on Monday night after a day where temperatures pushed 40 degrees and strong winds hit the region.

Forest Fire Management incident controller Darren Shiell said that all containment lines had held.

"All fires have crew on them patrolling to make sure hot spots on the containment lines are dealt with," he said.

A suspected lightning strike caused a fire near Bessiebelle on Monday afternoon but Mr Shiell said he was "very confident" crews would also have that fire under control.

He said the Lake Condah fire was in "tricky" terrain that made it difficult for firefighters to create a mineral earth containment line, with crews instead using a sprinkler system.

"It's been going for over a week, there's no active flame, it is more hot spots within big stumps or in big rocks, where the crews can't get to," Mr Shiell said.

Gunditj Mirring man Roger Morris was patrolling land at the Lake Condah Mission in a ute towing a slip-on.

The fire threatened nearby Aboriginal sites, and came within 500 metres from the mission buildings last week, but has stopped at the Darlot Creek near the structures.

Mr Morris was grateful firefighters kept the blaze at bay in extreme conditions yesterday.

"Thankfully it hasn't got too much out of control," he said.

"With the strong wind they are worried about it taking off on the southern end."

Emergency services have also lined the Heywood Recreational Reserve with tents, a pop-up laundry and kitchen to form a base camp for people fighting fires.

The camp, called "Woody", housed up to 40 people on Monday night and can serve meals to up to 300 firefighters.

Mr Shiell said Heywood community members had helped begin to construct the tents on Friday.

"The reason it is there is for Monday's extreme weather, if we got an escape or a fire starting we would have incoming resources, we have been using local accommodation providers until now and they are full with tourists," he said.

Mr Shiell said the base camp would likely be there for at least another week and at least 100 personnel would likely be involved in fighting the fires during the New Year period.

"It's not that we get through Monday and everyone walks away," he said.

Terry Sim, who lives on the edge of the east side of Budj Bim National Park, said he and his elderly neighbours left their homes on Monday in case the Lake Condah fire got away.

He said his house was within half a kilometre of the trees.

Mr Sim said there was "simply no way" he or his neighbours could defend their properties if the fire broke the southern boundary in the predicted high winds and hot weather.

He said he had taken his dogs and a few possessions.

"Knowing the risk, there's no sense staying," Mr Sim said.

"If it runs over the hill with the wind behind it I'm not going to be able to fight it.

"There are more important things to fight."

urn:contentItem:5N2R-TBY1-F0JP-W2NT-00000-00REMEMBER WHEN2017-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 40REMEMBER WHEN

GOLD COAST BULLETIN Thursday, October 30, 2003

FIRESTORMS roared down the northern corridor, destroying two homes and other buildings.

One home was lost in Jenkins Court, Coomera, and another in Fairview Drive, Willow Vale.

Rural district Inspector Bernard Trembath said conditions were beginning to ease, however the situation was still critical.

"Conditions have been kind to us this evening," he said.

"The winds have dropped and the weather has cooled off which has enabled us to begin backburning operations and other strategic plans.

"Most of the fires are not yet under control but we are making inroads." As firefighters continued to battle, Energex crews were working to restore power to 11,000 homes in 19 suburbs.

Winds gusting between 80km/h and 100km/h brought down powerlines and trees. An Energex spokeswoman said 50 per cent of power had been restored by 6pm and crews were confident all would be restored.

More than 2000 homes in Andrews, Burleigh Heads and Currumbin Valley were hit, after roaring westerlies brought down a major 30,000-volt line in Reedy Creek Rd just before 11am.

Energex crews were still working to restore that line last night. The major fires were in Upper Coomera, which was under control, and a large forest fire burning on two fronts at Willow Vale, which was still burning.The blaze in Upper Coomera was believed to have started from powerlines arcing together shortly after 1pm.

urn:contentItem:5XG2-BC81-DXX7-H2KH-00000-00Are Victorians living on the fringes of our cities prepared for the bushfire season?2019-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisAre Victorians living on the fringes of our cities prepared for the bushfire season?By Nicole Mills

As New South Wales and Queensland grapple with devastating bushfires which have arrived unusually early, Victorians are getting battle-ready for the predicted emergencies that lie ahead this summer.

While fields in some parts of this southern state remain green, it will not be long before the landscape turns various shades of yellow and brown.

In Bannockburn, a small town located about 30 minutes north of the Geelong city centre, the wind tears across the open paddocks, bending waist-high grass flat to the ground.

It is not hard to imagine what would happen if a fire ripped through here in the dry heat of summer.

But the demographics of this once rural shire are changing fast and the influx of new residents is bringing significant challenges ahead of fire season.

Australian Bureau of Statistics data from March showed Bannockburn had a growth rate of 3.6 per cent, making it the ninth-fastest-growing regional area in the state.

Small residential blocks now line the edge of open farmland.

Golden Plains Shire fire prevention officer Matthew Sims said it was a situation mirrored by many rapidly growing areas on Melbourne's peri-urban fringe.

"We do have a lot of people moving from outside the area who might not know what to do in relation to fire prevention," he said.

"There's a lot of lifestyle blocks. There's a lot of people that have come out of Ballarat and Geelong with horses or a couple of sheep, and that do want to live in this lifestyle.

"But they just have to be mindful of the fire danger."

It is his job to inform them of their legal obligations.

Each November, Mr Sims and colleague Lynette Sorgiovanni travel across the large shire, issuing infringement notices to anyone whose property poses an unnecessary risk.

It could be as simple as long grass which needs mowing, but more recently they have noticed an increase in people ignoring their properties' planning permits and opting for cheap plastic water tanks which do not meet the requirements set by the Country Fire Authority (CFA), who need to tap into private water supplies in an emergency.

While the majority of people act on the infringement notices issued by the council, the rest are slapped with a $1,652 fineand contractors are sent in to do the work at the property owners' expense.

Some residents get annoyed at what they view as council revenue raising, but the shire insists it would be happy if it never issued another fine (fines whichare mandated by the statewide CFA Act, not local government laws).

It would mean the entire region was safer.

"Earlier this year there was a grass fire within Golden Plains Shire. We lost 1500 hectares of land," Mr Simms said.

"There was a house that was smack bang in the middle which completed all the fire prevention works throughout the fire danger period.

"That house survived even though everything around it was destroyed."

Virtual reality helps preparation

In Colac, about 70 staff and volunteers from various agencies gathered in the incident control centre to respond to a fictional emergency.

Michael Harper is running the exercise, which is dubbed White Lightning.

This fire and its spread are computer generated, and officers will have to address a public meeting created using virtual reality.

But Mr Harper insists that "in here, it's real".

He knows what can happen when mistakes are made; when agencies aren't prepared.

Victorians are still traumatised by the 173 lives lost on Black Saturday in 2009.

"Every year we make slight changes, which come out of debriefs from the previous fire season," he said.

"We want people to practice what they're going to have to enact ... and more importantly we like people to build relationships between the agencies so that when we have a fire in the landscape, people know who they're talking to and we're able to work together better."

Don't rely on us, CFA warns

CFA South West acting assistant chief officer Peter Creak said preparation was built around worst case scenarios.

He said it was an approach homeowners should take too.

"In a worst-case scenario, we're not going to be able to get a fire truck to every house in a high risk area," he said.

"What we'll do is focus our efforts on protecting as many of the community as possible and that might mean that there are parts of the community that won't have immediate access to our resources.

"So you need to make a decision as part of your bushfire plan about where you're going to be, and that might be away from your property."

Mr Creak also warned people not to rely on one method of gathering information.

"You need to be continually reviewing the information that's out there because in an emergency, the situation can change very, very quickly," he said.

"You might be very comfortable one minute and then a fire might change or the weather might worsen, and your situation might become more difficult very soon."

Are we getting better at it?

Emergency Management Victoria commissioner Andrew Crisp said above-average fire conditions were expected in the greater Gippsland region.

"What that means is we're more likely to see protracted campaign fires," he said.

And while parts of the state have had some good rainfall, Mr Crisp said there was always a risk of fire.

But he said agencies were getting better at bushfire preparation every year and Victoria was "well and truly ready" for this fire season.

"Victorians should be comfortable and confident," he said.

"Yes, we live in Victoria, we're coming into summer, fire is part of our history ... however, we have got better at how we actually prepare for those fires."

Mr Crisp warned it was not just up to fire agencies to prepare.

"It's a shared responsibility," he said.

He recommended every Victorian download the Vic Emergency app, know who the emergency broadcaster is and make a plan, including when they were going to leave.

The growing fuel load

Mr Crisp said planned burns were an important part of reducing the fuel load, but conducting them was becoming more difficult.

"Our fire season is longer and therefore the times when they can actually do their planned burns is shrinking," he said.

"So they're looking at other ways that they can achieve the same outcomes. So looking at traditional owner methods like burning in wintertime.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria already use mechanical means so using bulldozers and other equipment."

Are there enough CFA volunteers?

After the Victorian Government passed its controversial fire service reforms earlier this year, some predicted a mass exodus of CFA volunteers.

But Mr Crisp said the numbers were stable.

"I'm very confident in terms of volunteer numbers. They have been stable for a number of years and I've been reassured yet again for this year we basically have the same numbers that we had last year," he said.

"I get out to a lot of brigades and I hear nothing other than that they're committed to keeping their community safe."

He said most of the fires last season were actually on public land, which was the responsibility of Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"Every year they bring on more than 600 project firefighters and they've increased their numbers this year," he said.

"So you've got FFM Vic, you've got Parks Victoria, there's a whole range of other paid firefighters that you've actually got to think about in terms of where the fires actually occur. It's not just about the volunteers.

"Volunteers do an absolutely wonderful job and we need them in terms of their numbers for that surge capacity. But they're one part of the picture."

Each November, Mr Sims and colleague Lynette Sorgiovanni travel across the large shire, issuing infringement notices to anyone whose property poses an unnecessary risk.

It could be as simple as long grass which needs mowing, but more recently they have noticed an increase in people ignoring their properties' planning permits and opting for cheap plastic water tanks which do not meet the requirements set by the Country Fire Authority (CFA), who need to tap into private water supplies in an emergency.

While the majority of people act on the infringement notices issued by the council, the rest are slapped with a $1,652 fineand contractors are sent in to do the work at the property owners' expense.

Some residents get annoyed at what they view as council revenue raising, but the shire insists it would be happy if it never issued another fine (fines whichare mandated by the statewide CFA Act, not local government laws).

It would mean the entire region was safer.

"Earlier this year there was a grass fire within Golden Plains Shire. We lost 1500 hectares of land," Mr Simms said.

"There was a house that was smack bang in the middle which completed all the fire prevention works throughout the fire danger period.

"That house survived even though everything around it was destroyed."

Virtual reality helps preparation

In Colac, about 70 staff and volunteers from various agencies gathered in the incident control centre to respond to a fictional emergency.

Michael Harper is running the exercise, which is dubbed White Lightning.

This fire and its spread are computer generated, and officers will have to address a public meeting created using virtual reality.

But Mr Harper insists that "in here, it's real".

He knows what can happen when mistakes are made; when agencies aren't prepared.

Victorians are still traumatised by the 173 lives lost on Black Saturday in 2009.

"Every year we make slight changes, which come out of debriefs from the previous fire season," he said.

"We want people to practice what they're going to have to enact ... and more importantly we like people to build relationships between the agencies so that when we have a fire in the landscape, people know who they're talking to and we're able to work together better."

Don't rely on us, CFA warns

CFA South West acting assistant chief officer Peter Creak said preparation was built around worst case scenarios.

He said it was an approach homeowners should take too.

"In a worst-case scenario, we're not going to be able to get a fire truck to every house in a high risk area," he said.

"What we'll do is focus our efforts on protecting as many of the community as possible and that might mean that there are parts of the community that won't have immediate access to our resources.

"So you need to make a decision as part of your bushfire plan about where you're going to be, and that might be away from your property."

Mr Creak also warned people not to rely on one method of gathering information.

"You need to be continually reviewing the information that's out there because in an emergency, the situation can change very, very quickly," he said.

"You might be very comfortable one minute and then a fire might change or the weather might worsen, and your situation might become more difficult very soon."

Are we getting better at it?

Emergency Management Victoria commissioner Andrew Crisp said above-average fire conditions were expected in the greater Gippsland region.

"What that means is we're more likely to see protracted campaign fires," he said.

And while parts of the state have had some good rainfall, Mr Crisp said there was always a risk of fire.

But he said agencies were getting better at bushfire preparation every year and Victoria was "well and truly ready" for this fire season.

"Victorians should be comfortable and confident," he said.

"Yes, we live in Victoria, we're coming into summer, fire is part of our history ... however, we have got better at how we actually prepare for those fires."

Mr Crisp warned it was not just up to fire agencies to prepare.

"It's a shared responsibility," he said.

He recommended every Victorian download the Vic Emergency app, know who the emergency broadcaster is and make a plan, including when they were going to leave.

The growing fuel load

Mr Crisp said planned burns were an important part of reducing the fuel load, but conducting them was becoming more difficult.

"Our fire season is longer and therefore the times when they can actually do their planned burns is shrinking," he said.

"So they're looking at other ways that they can achieve the same outcomes. So looking at traditional owner methods like burning in wintertime.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria already use mechanical means so using bulldozers and other equipment."

Are there enough CFA volunteers?

After the Victorian Government passed its controversial fire service reforms earlier this year, some predicted a mass exodus of CFA volunteers.

But Mr Crisp said the numbers were stable.

"I'm very confident in terms of volunteer numbers. They have been stable for a number of years and I've been reassured yet again for this year we basically have the same numbers that we had last year," he said.

"I get out to a lot of brigades and I hear nothing other than that they're committed to keeping their community safe."

He said most of the fires last season were actually on public land, which was the responsibility of Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"Every year they bring on more than 600 project firefighters and they've increased their numbers this year," he said.

"So you've got FFM Vic, you've got Parks Victoria, there's a whole range of other paid firefighters that you've actually got to think about in terms of where the fires actually occur. It's not just about the volunteers.

"Volunteers do an absolutely wonderful job and we need them in terms of their numbers for that surge capacity. But they're one part of the picture."

urn:contentItem:5XTD-SJY1-JD34-V1HG-00000-00Six blazes still burning as firefighters work to contain fires before warm weekend2019-12-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Six blazes still burning as firefighters work to contain fires before warm weekendAndrew Thomson

Firefighters will be working to contain three main blazes in the Heywood district before warmer weather and potentially dangerous winds are expected at the coming weekend.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Heywood incident controller Mark Mellington said a band of lightning accompanied a cool change on Friday and had resulted in a number of fires in the region during the past couple of days.

He said fires became active on Friday night, Saturday and Sunday after those lightning strikes.

Mr Mellington said six fires were still going in the region while a number of others were contained or now considered under control.

"We responded Friday evening to a number of fires and then several more on Saturday and then again on Sunday," he said.

"Lightning strikes may hit something flammable but then smoulder until the right conditions before igniting, whether that be warmth during the day or winds."

Mr Mellington said concerns were held in relation to a fire in the Weecurra Forest on the Digby-Strathdownie Road.

He said there was some activity in that largely contained 640-hectare fire.

The other priority is the Crawford River fire, just west of Hotspur, which has so far covered 1570 hectares.

"We've been doing a lot of work with ground crews and heavy plant (machinery) and lot of aircraft fire bombers taking on that fire," he said.

"There's quite a bit of fire edge and it's in steep gullies and tall timber. There's quite a bit of work to be done.

"There's a lot of smoke and will be more with increased fire activity. We're really working hard to ensure these fires are wrapped as soon as possible."

Mr Mellington said concerns were also held about a fire at Lake Condah where both helicopters and fixed wing planes were bombing.

"It's very challenging country to get access to and do work on," he said.

"The Budj Bim area is also a world heritage area and of really significant cultural values so we are mindful and respectful of working through any issues with the Gunditjmirring Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation."

Mr Merllington said the fire had covered 286 hectares.

"There's a lot of planning going into that. We'll be doing burning operations to minimise the spread," he said.

"Virtually all the fire is on the indigenous protected area while the others are largely in state forests.

"Plantations have also been impacted but not a significant amount at this point."

The incident controller said that currently the weather was pretty benign but that was expected to change to warmer windier conditions next weekend.

"We're really working hard to get on top of these fires by then," he said.

"Communities are going to see smoke from the fires and the back burning operations.

"We are going to control or bring these fires out to roads and tracks and put in containment lines.

"People need to monitor the emergency.vic app and stay advised," he said.

South West Coast state member Roma Britnell went to Heywood for an update briefing on Monday.

"It's pretty serious stuff stretching across the state. The firefighters are doing an amazing job," she said.

"The Budj Bim fire in particular is challenging county. There is a lot of fuel and it's in a really difficult position."

urn:contentItem:5XWF-1XR1-JD34-V3G8-00000-00Firefighters gear up for more blazes to follow Christmas2019-12-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Firefighters gear up for more blazes to follow ChristmasAdrian Rollins

More than 2000 firefighters spent Christmas Day working to establish and strengthen containment lines for blazes across NSW ahead of a heatwave due to hit the state late this week.

Milder temperatures on Christmas Day and Boxing Day have provided weary fire crews with a welcome respite from last week's catastrophic conditions in which around 100 homes were destroyed and two firefighters died.

"What we have seen today is a general easing in fire conditions and we expect that to continue tomorrow," a NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said. "That gives us the chance to establish or strengthen containment lines."

As of late afternoon on Christmas Day, there were still 74 bush and grass fires burning across the state, including almost 30 yet to be contained. All were advice level, reflecting the milder conditions.

Among the blazes still out of control is the large Currowan fire south-east of Canberra, which has burnt through more than 231,000 hectares between Batemans Bay and Sussex Inlet, while the adjacent Charleys Forest fire east of Braidwood, which is more than 32,000 hectares in size, was being brought under control.

The fires have forced the closure of Kings Highway south-east of Braidwood, forcing holidaymakers and other travelling to and from the South Coast to make lengthy detours either on the Snowy Mountains Highway through Cooma and Bega or the Illawarra Highway.

Meanwhile, the massive Gospers Mountain fire, which has burnt through almost 500,000 hectares of Wollemi National Park, remains out of control, and Sydney remain ringed by 11 blazes, five of which were listed as out of control.

NSW remains under a seven-day state of emergency declared by Premier Gladys Berejiklian last Thursday, empowering the RFS Commissioner to order evacuations, close roads, enter or seize properties, order the shutdown of essential services like electricity and gas, and direct and control government agencies and resources.

READ MORE:

Dozens of buildings destroyed by Currowan fire 'Various shades of black': Walnut farm's crop wiped out in Currowan fire At least 873 homes destroyed in NSW fires The declaration will come up for review today.

According to the RFS's latest impact assessment, issued on Christmas Eve, almost 1000 homes have been destroyed since the fire season began on July 1, as well as more than 2000 outbuildings and 68 facilities. The service said a further 7824 homes, 7053 outbuildings and 615 facilities had been saved as a result of the effort of fire crews.

The RFS spokesman said more than 2000 volunteers and crews were working on fire containment lines on Christmas Day as part of preparations for a heatwave expected to send temperatures soaring from Friday through to New Year's Day.

He said the firefighters were being rotated during the day in order to allow them to spend time with their families, and special meals were being provided.

"Even though its Christmas Day, the work needs to go on, but we are trying to look after them," the spokesman said.

Those on duty include crews drawn from across NSW.

The RFS said it had been overwhelmed by community support, including the donation of a huge amount of goods.

But the service said that it had received so much that in many places "we have little room [left] to hold these supplies". It has asked people to instead donate funds.

"What [communities] told us they need most right now is ... money."

"It's very challenging country to get access to and do work on," he said.

"The Budj Bim area is also a world heritage area and of really significant cultural values so we are mindful and respectful of working through any issues with the Gunditjmirring Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation."

Mr Merllington said the fire had covered 286 hectares.

"There's a lot of planning going into that. We'll be doing burning operations to minimise the spread," he said.

"Virtually all the fire is on the indigenous protected area while the others are largely in state forests.

"Plantations have also been impacted but not a significant amount at this point."

The incident controller said that currently the weather was pretty benign but that was expected to change to warmer windier conditions next weekend.

"We're really working hard to get on top of these fires by then," he said.

"Communities are going to see smoke from the fires and the back burning operations.

"We are going to control or bring these fires out to roads and tracks and put in containment lines.

"People need to monitor the emergency.vic app and stay advised," he said.

South West Coast state member Roma Britnell went to Heywood for an update briefing on Monday.

"It's pretty serious stuff stretching across the state. The firefighters are doing an amazing job," she said.

"The Budj Bim fire in particular is challenging county. There is a lot of fuel and it's in a really difficult position."

urn:contentItem:5VGK-MV71-F0J6-J4TN-00000-00Representing Redesdale: Mural tells of community's resilience2019-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATERepresenting Redesdale: Mural tells of community's resilienceEmma D'Agostino

THE water tank at Redesdale's Agnes Mudford Reserve has been transformed into a work of art.

A mural marking the 10th anniversary of Black Saturday serves as a representation of the community's resilience.

Ideas for the piece, which runs around the tank's side, were drawn from the community's experiences.

"We wanted something everyone could look at and connect to in some way," Kym De Lany, of Redesdale and District Association, said.

She was struck by how much the project had meant to people.

About 100 people attended Friday's mural unveiling. They included Country Fire Authority members from Redesdale and Heathcote, Forest Fire Management Victoria personnel, school children, community groups and community members.

All three levels of government were represented, with Member for Bendigo Lisa Chesters, Member for Euroa Steph Ryan, and Greater Bendigo mayor Margaret O'Rourke among the dignitaries.

RELATED: Black Saturday 10 years on - Redesdale remembers the bushfires

Ms De Lany recalled image maker Damien Arena's observation from the project's community consultation period.

He had told her so many people were keen to talk about what they wanted from the mural.

"They really care," Arena, who was present during Friday's unveiling, had told Ms De Lany.

Regional Arts Victoria's Joe Toohey spoke about the organisation's support for the project, which was considered worthy of funding partially because it encouraged people to share their stories.

"That is the way you build and maintain empathy in communities," Mr Toohey said.

"It is important to be continuing to tell these stories."

RELATED: Black Saturday: 10 years on - the Bendigo and Redesdale fires

Arena said he wanted to show in the mural a sense of the whole community, not just showing a fire happening or someone from Redesdale in the aftermath.

"I wanted to show what it meant to be part of a community like this."

He said the consultation period had shown him how quickly the community had come together after Black Saturday.

After all the consultation and planning, the mural was completed in about three days.

Arena was hopeful it would be part of the community for many years to come.

A total of 7086 hectares burned in Redesdale on Black Saturday. Fourteen homes were destroyed.

"It's a day no-one will ever, ever forget," Member for Euroa, Steph Ryan said.

"For some people 10 years is the blink of an eye and for others it's an eternity."

urn:contentItem:5XSS-VY51-JD34-V0VP-00000-00Bega MP Andrew Constance says it is time for debate on climate change2019-12-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisBega MP Andrew Constance says it is time for debate on climate changeAlbert McKnight

Member for Bega Andrew Constance said while it is time for a debate on climate change, when it came to its impact on bushfires there are many other contributing factors to take into account.

"Yes it's time to have the debate, but it's very disappointing that in our region this next four days is going to be potentially like hell on earth," Mr Constance said on Wednesday.

"Those fires that are raging, at Braidwood and the Currowan forest fire in particular, we've now seen 16 homes lost in that fire.

"We've got volunteers working their guts out and any big debate that needs to happen from activists needs to be couched in the context that we have men and women in our community who are fighting very hard to protect us."

READ MORE: Merimbula climate protest during McCormack visit organised by action group

On a day when smoke had drifted south from northern fires to cover the Bega Valley, Mr Constance was speaking to Australian Community Media at Tathra, the site of a bushfire in 2018.

His comments follow Premier Gladys Berejiklian's remarks last month that it was not yet the time for such a debate as she wanted to focus on the state's bushfire emergency.

On Thursday, the NSW government declared the second state of emergency of the bushfire season.

NSW Environment Minister Matt Kean recently reiterated the bushfires were linked to climate change, but Mr Constance said bushfires needed to be looked at in context as there was "a raft of factors" that contributed to their occurrence including bushland management, hazard reduction burning, and how there "continues to be issues" around fire trails, containment lines and fuel loads.

"To look through it solely of the purview of climate change - we need to have the debate, but it's got to be done holistically around fires."

He said last election the NSW government made it clear it was going to work through its Climate Change Fund to "do a whole raft of things", including reduce emissions and "practical elements".

"But I think most people at the moment, they're more worried about the welfare of our local people out there fighting fires than some of the debate and quality of the debate that's going on currently," Mr Constance said.

READ MORE: Tathra Headland Walkway officially opened: It was 'hard fought for by the community'

When asked what he thought about calling for more action on climate change, he said the government's position had been "spelled out" and he supported the Climate Change Fund.

"I made it clear even as the Transport Minister, the best thing that people can do to reduce emissions is utilise the benefits of public transport," he said.

"That's very much been our focus in Sydney in terms of cars on the road.

"I want to reduce the diesel in particular that's going into communities because of the poisoning effects on the health of the community, and that means electrification of the state's bus fleet."

He said he has had a lot of people say they want to support the NSW Rural Fire Service during this time, but the best thing they could do was prepare their own homes.

READ MORE: Noisy welcome for Acting PM at airport| VIDEO, PHOTOS

"We have householders who at this stage are not heeding the warnings, preparing their properties, and if you want to put a volunteer at risk then the worst thing you can do is not go and take action in your place," he said.

"We need them to be given every opportunity to be able to protect property."

urn:contentItem:5W1H-VCH1-JD34-V3KX-00000-00Muddy river of destruction2019-05-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisMuddy river of destructionVivienne Jones

A couple has lost their Baranduda home after a "river of mud" inundated their house during Thursday night's downpour.

Paul Braut and Rach Gallagher were left "heartbroken" after 120mm of rain hit the suburb in a few hours, destroying their Barton Drive home.

When they returned the next morning the house and cars were under more than a metre of mud.

"We actually left just before it hit and when we got to Barnawartha we got a phone call from a neighbour who said our house was inundated," Mr Braut said.

"The two dogs were running around outside when we arrived, they had gotten out through the big hole in the house where a window used to be.

"I'd say they were floating around in the lounge room on the couches for a while there.

"There was a three-foot wall of mud and water coming down the hill and straight into our house."

Mr Braut had been in the house for 11 years and lost his shed and a few cars were lost in a fire seven years ago.

"But what can you do?" he said.

Mr Braut said draining wasn't sufficient in the area and a recent burn off meant debris was on the ground.

"After the burn off up the hill there, all the silt and debris was left on the ground and the water just picked it up. That is now all in my house," he said.

"We are in a really bad spot here at the end of the court and it is like a funnel that comes off the hill and straight into our house.

"The neighbours said it was like lava coming down the road."

One of their neighbours Tiffany Smart said it was "too late" to get their horses out of the mud overnight.

"They were stuck in mud over their knees overnight," she said.

"It is too dangerous to move animals like that in the dark so we just had to hope they would be OK."

Forest Fire Management assistant chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said it was "too early" to determine the impacts the planned burns had on the rain event.

"We know as a matter of fact that any areas that have been burnt we are going to see an increase in run off and debris flow but it is actually far too early for us to determine the level of impact that the burn had on debris flow and how that may have impacted residents," he said.

Victoria SES assistant chief officer and incident controller Keith O'Brien said they had 55 calls for assistance across the Wodonga and Baranduda areas.

"Those requests for assistance ranged from a tree down traffic hazard, flood water on roads, right up to building damage and water through houses," he said.

There was also one rescue of a car stuck in flood waters.

A couple has lost their Baranduda home after a "river of mud" inundated their house during Thursday night's downpour.

Paul Braut and Rach Gallagher were left "heartbroken" after 120mm of rain hit the suburb in a few hours, destroying their Barton Drive home.

When they returned the next morning the house and cars were under more than a metre of mud.

"We actually left just before it hit and when we got to Barnawartha we got a phone call from a neighbour who said our house was inundated," Mr Braut said.

"The two dogs were running around outside when we arrived, they had gotten out through the big hole in the house where a window used to be.

"I'd say they were floating around in the lounge room on the couches for a while there.

"There was a three-foot wall of mud and water coming down the hill and straight into our house."

Mr Braut had been in the house for 11 years and lost his shed and a few cars were lost in a fire seven years ago.

"But what can you do?" he said.

Mr Braut said draining wasn't sufficient in the area and a recent burn off meant debris was on the ground.

"After the burn off up the hill there, all the silt and debris was left on the ground and the water just picked it up. That is now all in my house," he said.

"We are in a really bad spot here at the end of the court and it is like a funnel that comes off the hill and straight into our house.

"The neighbours said it was like lava coming down the road."

One of their neighbours Tiffany Smart said it was "too late" to get their horses out of the mud overnight.

"They were stuck in mud over their knees overnight," she said.

"It is too dangerous to move animals like that in the dark so we just had to hope they would be OK."

"We know as a matter of fact that any areas that have been burnt we are going to see an increase in run off and debris flow but it is actually far too early for us to determine the level of impact that the burn had on debris flow and how that may have impacted residents," he said.

"Those requests for assistance ranged from a tree down traffic hazard, flood water on roads, right up to building damage and water through houses," he said.

urn:contentItem:5NJR-NH91-F031-X378-00000-00Reconciliation at the heart of central Victoria's indigenous fire management program2017-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisReconciliation at the heart of central Victoria's indigenous fire management programLarissa Romensky

Reconciliation is playing an important part in the way planned burns will be conducted in central Victoria.

Aboriginal traditional burning practices are being incorporated into forest fire management are more about people than managing fires.

While there has been ceremonial lighting of fires by Aboriginal Elders and exploration of traditional burning practices for some years, the partnership between Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation will see traditional burning practices incorporated into the existing fuel management program.

"It's actually implementing cultural knowledge and aspirations," said Trent Nelson, Dja Dja Wurrung Ranger Team Leader with Parks Victoria.

The traditional burns are being conducted in wake of the $310 million recently announced in the state budget for planned burning and bushfire preparedness.

Mr Nelson said fire management techniques were crucial for reconciliation.

"Trying to implement our purpose as Dja Dja Wurrung people and put ourselves back in the landscape and fire management are some of the key tools," he said. a

"Dja Dja Wurrung Country needs healing and also Dja Dja Wurrung people need healing."

Slowing down the burning process

Some of the changes to the way planned burns will be managed will be the cessation of drip torches.

These hand-held fuel filled devices with a faster acceleration rate will be replaced with a more controlled "slower" approach using a more traditional drip torch made of a grass tree stick with red bush stringy bark wrapped around it.

"It's using the natural resources that are there in the bush and within the ground and using our traditional methods of actually lighting fire though a firestick," Mr Nelson said.

"Cool burns basically take a lot of time to implement on the ground because we're not putting that much fuel into it,

"From that we burn out in a circular pattern out into the bush and it creates a bit of a mosaic effect.

"Our country is upside down country"

Assistant Chief Fire Officer for the region from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP), Scott Falconer said fuel reduction was also about "getting the country back to what it was".

Much of the central Victorian region had been mined "to with an inch of its life" and coupled with heavy forestation had contributed to a vastly changed landscape.

"It's not just about reducing fuels but it's actually about healing country as well," Mr Falconer said.

Mr Nelson agreed, "Our country is upside down country."

He said after 170 years of the land being "disturbed and broken up and mismanaged" it would take an equally long time to reverse things.

"It's probably going to take that again, maybe double to get it back to close to what our old people managed it," he said.

Whereas he conceded there were areas beyond repair, there were still some remaining areas that showed potential and would benefit from introduced native vegetation and seeds.

"There's still native grasses. There's still vegetation there in low numbers we can work on, and we can build and use, " Mr Nelson said.

Using fire as a technique to re-introduce vegetation would also extend to animals.

"Because a lot of areas you look at there is no fauna as well around those areas when our old people were managing country," Mr Nelson said.

"We want to bring the fauna back in for a reason,

"And it's not just for hunting it's to actually heal that country and heal ourselves."

"It gives us respect"

Crucial to the implementation of this initiative was involving elders from the onset rather than at the implementation stage.

"It gives us respect, it gives us a little bit of ownership as well of what's going on and its a really simple thing to do," Mr Nelson said.

For the first time elders elders were "back out on country".

"They're talking about the country, they're feeling different things. They're connecting and were learning as well from them of what they're seeing," Mr Nelson said.

"We can gain our knowledge from our old people - its' our cultural boundaries and respect that we build up in nature."

urn:contentItem:5RJD-K0H1-JD34-V1SM-00000-00Burrumbeet2018-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4BurrumbeetVictoria Stone-Meadows

Following the damage and refuse left behind at Lake Burrumbeet on Australia Day, The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) and City of Ballarat have both distanced themselves from management responsibilities of the area.

DELWP are officially responsible for the management of Lake Burrumbeet after City of Ballarat handed over management in 2015, except in the case of the caravan park and the racecourse.

City of Ballarat Director of Infrastructure and Environment Terry Demeo said council have no plans to take back over management of the lake campgrounds despite recent events.

"Following extensive negotiations with the Crown, Council resolved to relinquish its committee of management status over Lake Burrumbeet in 2014, and the handover to DELWP was completed in 2015," he said.

"At this stage, Council has no plans to seek the reversal of that decision."

While DELWP are responsible for management of the campgrounds at the lake, Forest Fire Management Victoria Midlands District Manager, Jasmine Filmer said decisions about the area are not made by DELWP alone.

"Management decisions are made in consultation with partners and key stakeholders," she said.

"DELWP manages Lake Burrumbeet in partnership with the City of Ballarat, the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation, Fisheries Victoria and the Glenelg Hopkins CMA."

Ms Filmer said enforecmet of the campground rules are enforced but it is the responsibility of campers in the area to treat each other, the provided facilities, and the land with respect.

"Appropriate use of the lake is guided by legislation and council local laws with officers from DELWP, Victoria Police, Fisheries Victoria, Game Management Authority, and City of Ballarat monitoring the lake area," she said.

"DELWP maintains the toilet facilities, but does not provide bins so campers are expected to take their rubbish home with them."

"DELWP's authorised officers monitor this camp site on a regular basis."â€‹

urn:contentItem:5MNT-Y0J1-F0J6-J32X-00000-00Big Desert fire burning north of Yanac2016-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisBig Desert fire burning north of YanacRex Martinich

THE Department of Environment is responding to reports of fire activity in the Big Desert about 47 kilometres north of Yanac.

The fire incident was first listed at 7.33pm on Friday.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning has issued an advice message for the Yanac, Netherby, Jeparit, Murrayville, Cowangie, Boinka, Danyo, Underbool, Telopea downs and Rainbow areas.

"There is no threat to communities," the message stated.

"Smoke may be smelled by nearby communities and on roads.

"The fire is currently not yet under control. Forest Fire Management are responding. Thunderstorms are expected overnight and resources will be back on site at first light."

The next fire update is expected by 11am Sunday or as the situation changes.

Live emergency information is available at online at emergency.vic.gov.au or via the FireReady smartphone and tablet app.

The Victorian Bushfire Information Line is available by phone via 1800 240 667.

Deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment can contact Victorian Bushfire Information Line via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.

For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 and ask them to telephone VBIL. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.

urn:contentItem:5T4V-YY71-JD34-V54T-00000-00$10.3 million investment embeds DELWP in Tallangatta community2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWS$10.3 million investment embeds DELWP in Tallangatta communitySophie Boyd

After years operating out of Tallangatta's old police station, residence and court house - with their depot hundreds of metres away - the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning is upgrading to new $10.3 milllion facility.

DELWP Forest Fire Management's regional manager Aaron Kennedy said the new building would bring their offices and the depot together under one roof, allowing for increased efficiency.

"It's a fantastic announcement for Fire Forest Management Victoria, local staff and it's a great announcement for the community," he said.

"This will see DELWP embedded in the community for another 40 or 50 years, which is fantastic given we employ so many staff from the area."

In announcing the plan on Wednesday, Member for Northern Victoria Jaclyn Symes said the facility would streamline operations and improve services, including Fire Forest Management's ability to respond to fires.

She said Victorian government funded project would construct new depot sheds and infrastructure, improve health and safety requirements, and boost the region's economy.

RELATED:

Towong Shire mayor Aaron Scales said council had received the planning permit and would be advertising the plans in coming days.

He said the construction phase would create jobs in the region.

"We're very supportive of the announcement, it's a fantastic facility to have in Tallangatta," Cr Scales said.

Once open, 24 existing DELWP staff, 15 forest and fire officers and project fire fighters will transfer to the facility, as well as staff from Parks Victoria who share the current offices.

Mr Kennedy said the amalgamation of staff into one building would benefit the region and the employees.

"There are two main benefits to the community, it guarantees employment for locals since a lot of our permanent and contracted staff are from the area," he said.

"Secondly the community will see improved response times and the co-ordinating of emergency responses in the summer and the rest of the year."

Mr Kennedy said the new building would incorporate an incident control centre to centralise emergency responses.

He said there would also be a meeting room available for the community to use.

Ms Symes said a proposed greenfield site provides scope for future expansion.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-DSB1-F0J6-J3NS-00000-00Committed career in fire management rewarded with honour2018-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:33:57ZLexisNexisNEWSCommitted career in fire management rewarded with honourNatalie Croxon

A career in the environmental and emergency management fields spanning 38 years has seen Russell Manning awarded the Australian Fire Service Medal this Australia Day.

Mr Manning said he was honoured to receive the accolade, not just for himself but on behalf of the public land firefighting staff who do a "great job".

"I'm really passionate about the work that we do," Mr Manning said.

"I really like the emergency management space and working in teams in emergency management situations to protect our communities."

Mr Manning, a Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning project manager based in Bendigo, started his career in the works crew at Wyperfeld National Park in the Mallee.

Mr Manning's career has taken him across the state, with stints in Melbourne, Gippsland and the Mallee.

He was working in Bendigo as fire and emergency assistant manager when the Black Saturday fires struck.

Other roles have included assistant ranger, ranger-in-charge, Forest Fire district manager, incident controller and operations officer.

His work has not been restricted to in Victoria: he has participated in emergency deployments to the USA to assist in fighting fires, and in 2011 went to Christchurch in New Zealand to help in the wake of the city's disastrous earthquake.

Looking forward to the future, Mr Manning would like to help bring through the next generation of firefighters.

"What I'd like to be doing in... the next five years is to be more involved in mentoring and training incident control staff," he said.

A statement of Mr Manning's achievements in relation to the Australia Fire Service Medal said he was especially committed to collaborating with other agencies.

"His leadership in this area has enabled excellent cross agency responses to major fire events with great benefits to the community of Victoria," it read.
